_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
Ft. Pierce, Florida
Executive Summary

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Allied Universal Corporation's accidental release risk management plan involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and maintenance and management practices.  The elements of the plan are intended to prevent and minimize the accidental releases of extremely hazardous substances (chlorine, anhydrous ammonia and sulfur dioxide) used on site.  The Allied facility emergency response program involves the preparation of response plans that are tailored to the facility and the emergency response services available in the community.  Allied's emergency response program is in compliance with the EPA and OSHA Emergency Response Program requirements and is modeled after the "One Plan".

DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Allied Universal Corporation repackages chlorine and sulfur dioxide into 150-pound cylinders and one ton containers.  In addition, chlorine is utilized by Allied to manufacturer 10.5%-15% (by weight) sodium hypochlorite, and sulfur dioxide is utilized to manufacturer 40% (by weight) sodium bisulfite.  The facility includes a sidetrack for unloading 90-ton chlorine and sulfur dioxide railcars. A production building is used for packaging the cylinders and ton containers and for sodium hypochlorite and sodium bisulfite production.  All instrument controls for the chlorine and sulfur dioxide railcar unloading, cylinder and ton container packaging and sodium bisulfite production are located in the packaging building. The instrument controls for sodium hypochlorite manufacturing is located in the sodium hypochlorite manufacturing area.  Anhydrous ammonia is stored onsite in a 12,000-gallon aboveground storage tank.  Anhydrous ammonia is repackaged into 150-pound cylinders.  The facility is staffed during all hours of operations.

Based upon the program criteria as set forth in the Risk Manageme

nt Rule, including EPA's definition of a "covered process", the chlorine, anhydrous ammonia and sulfur dioxide processes at this facility are subject to Program 3 planning.

WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

An offsite consequence analysis was conducted that included consideration of two chlorine and one sulfur dioxide release scenarios, identified as "worst-case release" and/or "alternative scenario".  The worst-case scenario is defined by EPA, which states that the "owner shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released as a gas over 10 minutes," due to an unspecified failure.  Because the probability of such a release occurring is very remote, an alternative scenario, defined as "more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario", was also analyzed.

Atmospheric dispersion modeling was performed to determine the distance traveled by the chlorine and sulfur dioxide releases before its concentration decreases to the "toxic endpoint" selected by EPA.  The American Industrial Hygiene Association defines toxic endpoint as the "maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual's ability to take protective action".  

The worst-case release scenario at Allied's Ft. Pierce facility involves the failure of a 90-ton railcar of sulfur dioxide. Although Allied utilizes numerous administrative controls and active mitigation systems to minimize the consequences of such a release, no credit was taken for any mitigating factors in calculating the extent of the release.  This is in accordance to the EPA Risk Management Program worst-case scenario requirements (40 CFR ?68.25).   

For sulfur dioxide, when atmospheric dispersion modeling for the worst case scenario was performed using the RMP Guidance Program for Wastewater Treatment Plants, the

distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.0078 mg/L was estimated at 16 miles. The amount released is ninety (90) tons over a 10-minute period, providing a release rate of 18,000 lb./min. An estimate of residential population potentially affected of 160,030 was obtained using current census data.  

The alternative release scenario for sulfur dioxide involves the rupture of the flexible connections connected to the chlorine railcar, possibly due to human error, overpressurization or split or uncoupling due to equipment failure.   The amount of chlorine released is 8000 lb., at an average rate over five minutes (duration of the release) at 1600 lb./min (RMP Guidance Program for Wastewater Treatment Plants).  Using RMP*Comp, the toxic endpoint distance of 0.6 miles was calculated, and an estimate of residential population potentially affected of 0 was obtained using the most recent census data. 

The quantity of sulfur dioxide released would be mitigated by actuation of the actuator valve between the railcar unloading hose and the railcar valves.  Sulfur dioxide gas detectors are located in the area, and will sound an alarm if sulfur dioxide is released.  An additional mitigation system is the remote emergency shut-off valves installed at the facility.  Shut-off valves automatically stop the flow of sulfur dioxide from the railcar.  This will reduce significantly the amount of sulfur dioxide release in the case of a flexible connection rupture.

The alternative release scenario for chlorine involves the rupture of the flexible connections connected to the chlorine railcar, possibly due to human error, overpressurization or split or uncoupling due to equipment failure.   The amount of chlorine released is 1250 lb., at an average rate over five minutes (duration of the release) at 240 lb./min (Estimating the Area Affected by Chlorine Release, ed. 3; Chlorine Institute Pamphlet 74, Chlorine Institute: April, 1998).  Using RMP*Comp, the toxic endpoint distance of 0.3 miles was

calculated, and an estimate of residential population potentially affected of 0 was obtained using the most recent census data. 

The quantity of chlorine released would be mitigated by actuation of the excess flow valve in the railcar, actuator valve between the railcar unloading hose and railcar valves and the chlorine gas detectors.  An additional mitigation system is the remote emergency shut-off valves installed at the facility.  Shut-off valves automatically stop the flow of chlorine from the railcar.  This will reduce significantly the amount of chlorine release in the case of a flexible connection rupture.

The alternative release scenario for anhydrous ammonia involves the rupture of the flexible connections connected to the anhydrous ammonia cylinder during filling operations, possible due to human error, overpressurization or split or uncoupling due to equipment failure.  The amount of ammonia released is 1,800 lb., at an average rate over ten minutes (duration of the release) of 180 lb./minute (RMP Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants).  Using RMP*Comp, the toxic endpoint distance of 0.2 miles was calculated, and an estimate of residential population affected of 0 was obtained.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Allied accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

? Compliance with OSHA's Process Safety Management rule (29CFR ?1910.119) and EPA's Risk Management Plan (40 CFR ?68),
? Implementation of the National Association of Chemical Distributors Responsible Distribution Process Code (third-party Management Systems Verification in April 2001),
? Operator Function Specific and Emergency Response Training,
? Mechanical Integrity Program,
? Use of Chlorine Institute, Compressed Gas Association and other industry  recommended equipment,
? Use of effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators, facility managers and corporate managers,
? Pe

rformance of a process hazard analysis,
? Implementation of an internal and external auditing and inspection program.

Operator specific safety steps include availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by emergency response personnel during chemical emergencies to stop releases immediately.  The operators wear escape respirators and eye protection during connection/disconnection of the sulfur dioxide and chlorine supply and movement of the cylinders and one-ton containers.  Full-face respiratory protection is provided in the ammonia operations area. Employees are trained on the hazards and toxic properties of ammonia, chlorine and sulfur dioxide, presence of the gas detectors, equipment design and specifications and proper and safe handling procedures.

AUDITS

This facility has undergone an internal RMP and PSM audit in May of 2000, and an external State of Florida Department of Community Affairs RMP audit in March of 2001.

 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

One accidental release of chlorine occurred at the Ft. Pierce, Florida facility October 20, 1999.  As required by law, the chlorine release was reported to the U.S. National Response Center and the Florida State Warning Point.  There were no deaths, and only one public responder was injured.  Facility personnel were evacuated.  Both facility personnel and public emergency responders responded to and stopped the chlorine release.  It was determined that a one ton container valve had failed.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has an emergency response plan, which has been reviewed and updated in April of 2001.  The plan includes the following elements: 

? description of chlorine, sulfur dioxide and ammonia properties,
? recommended first aid for chlorine, sulfur dioxide and ammonia exposures,
? a list of all emergency equipment onsite and where such equipment is located, 
? list of onsite and offsite emergency response personnel and contact numbers, 
? detailed description of company perso

nnel, 
? government agencies that must be contacted in the event of a release, 
? procedures for handling the release, 
? evacuation plans,
? rescue of any personnel overcome by chlorine, anhydrous ammonia and sulfur dioxide,
? procedures for plan review and update.

The remainder of the emergency response plan describes the training program for onsite emergency response personnel and the requirement for the conducting of emergency drills annually to evaluate training and overall plan effectiveness.  


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Actuator valves and railcar access platforms were purchased and installed.  The actuator is installed between the flex hose and the angle valves on the chlorine and sulfur dioxide railcar.  These valves, when actuated, would prevent a release of chlorine and sulfur dioxide from the railcar at any point in the process.  Railcar platforms were installed at the chlorine and sulfur dioxide railcars to provide easy and safe access to the railcar manway during emergencies.  In addition, a chlorine, sulfur dioxide and sodium bisulfite scrubbing system has been installed for the chlorine and sulfur dioxide packaging building and bisuflite production tanks.

Ammonia scrubbing system has been installed.  Gas detection alarms as well as a roof to cover the ammonia storage tank have been planned for purchase and installation by the end of 2001.
